e:Sub-section.e:Title: Enroute clearance issuance and related procedures
e:Sub-section.x:div: All departing traffic are requested to contact Budapest Delivery 20 minutes prior to or - whatever is the latest - advising their call sign, aircraft type, destination and stand/gate number.

Delivery issues enroute clearances (clearance limit, ) and allocates squawk. When the flight is given a discrete departure route other than , the initial cleared altitude is given as well. See LHBP AD 2.22 FLIGHT PROCEDURES

When the flight is under slot allocation procedure all slot related coordinations are provided by Budapest Delivery including forwarding messages. Aircraft under slot allocation procedure shall continuously monitor Delivery frequency until further advise.

When the slot of the flight is expired (aircraft is not ready for start up at 10 minutes prior to CTOT) ATC will not issue start up clearance and operator (or its representative) shall request a new slot.

e:Sub-section.e:Title: Start up, push back and power back procedures
e:Sub-section.x:div: An aircraft may request startup clearance only when all doors are closed and the aircrew is ready for immediate start up At parking positions Terminal 1 : 01-06, R110-R117, 107-109, and at Terminal 2 : 31-38, 42-46 and 60-64, 66-69, R220-R223, R224-R227, start up engines and taxi out shall be performed by push back procedure. Towing bar for the given aircraft type shall be provided by the carrier or by the handling company. Additionally at stands 60-64, 66-69, R220-R223, R224-R227, and gates 31-38, 42-46, the push back tractor shall be connected. The only exceptions prop/turboprop aircraft making power back procedures on stands 60-64, 66-69, and R220-R223, R224-R227.
When aircrew is ready as described above, request ATC start up clearance from Budapest Delivery stating parking Terminal, and receipt of ATIS information by reading back QNH.
e:Sub-section.x:p: If the flight is subject to slot allocation procedure, the latest time to issue the start up clearance is 10 minutes prior to CTOT. (See LHBP AD 2.20 LOCAL REGULATIONS)
e:Sub-section.x:div: Upon receipt ATC start up clearance from Budapest Delivery, contact Budapest Apron 1 (Terminal 1) or Budapest Apron 2 (Terminal 2) respectively, for start up, push back guidance, notifying the stand number, and receipt of ATC start up clearance and readiness for start up and push back if necessary. After receiving the approval and instructions of Budapest Apron 1 or Budapest Apron 2 the aircraft may commence push back and/or start up engines with immediately informing or indicating the approval and facing of the aircraft, and other relevant information to the connected ground staff. Indicate to the ground staff the full release of parking brakes. The start up and push back procedure shall be initiated by the instructions of the connected ground staff. In case of multi engine aircraft separate clearance to start up should be requested for each engine from the ground staff. In case of no ground-cockpit connection, advise the Apron Unit, to provide Marshaller assistance to control the procedure. Visual signals provided by Marshaller during start up and push back, is in line with those of ICAO Annex 2 Appendix 1, MARSHALLING SIGNALS.
e:Sub-section.x:p: At parking positions 60-64, 66-69, and R220-R223, R224-R227 start up engines and taxi out could be performed with power back procedure for the prop and turbo prop aircraft, if the MTOW is not more than 30.000 kg in the guidance of Airfield Operations Service provided by the airport (Follow Me staff)The power back procedure is not applicable when Low Visibility Procedures are in force or the published breaking action is at or less than medium-to poor.

To leave the parking position in case of power back procedure shall be performed by the visual signals of the Airfield Operations Service (Follow Me staff) Aircraft making start up, push back or power back procedure should be ready for taxi within 4 minutes after off block time.
e:Sub-section.x:div: When engine start up or power back procedure is completed request taxi guidance from Budapest Apron 1, (Terminal 1) or Budapest Apron 2 (Terminal 2) and indicate receipt of clearance to the ground staff. The disconnected ground staff will give clearance to commence taxiing.
e:Sub-section.x:p: If an aircraft unable to comply with the above detailed conditions or has to break off start up procedure due to technical or any other reason, advise it immediately to Budapest Apron 1, or Budapest Apron 2.

x:p.x:em: Remark: generally, the connected ground staff is provided by the Ground Handling company. In case of special circumstances the Budapest Apron 1 or Budapest Apron 2 will provide the Airfield Operations Service (Follow Me staff) for star up, push back procedures.

e:Sub-section.e:Title: Taxi clearances
e:Sub-section.x:p: Crossing active RWY 13R/31L is permitted on specific clearance only. In the absence of a specific clearance to cross the active runway ahead aircraft shall not proceed beyond the relevant taxi holding position. Clearance for crossing the active runway is issued by Budapest TWR on 118,100 MHz frequency.

e:Sub-section.e:Title: Taxi procedures general
e:Sub-section.x:div: On Apron 1 and 2 Follow Me escort is not provided in normal conditions. The service is available only under special circumstances. (i.e. GAT, oversized ACFT, low visibility conditions, pilot requests)
The maximum taxi speed on the Aprons shall not exceed 16 KT and this speed shall be decreased if contamination on the surfaces deteriorates the braking action.

If departing or arriving aircraft must stop taxiing for any reason and it is necessary to open external door(s), aircraft shall report to ATC or APRON UNIT. Except cases of emergency, door(s) may be opened only in the presence of the border guards’ personnel.
Taxiing aircraft have to maintain continues radio contact with Budapest Ground or Budapest Tower while taxiing on the manoeuvring area.
Taxi holding points are designated as follows:

x:p.x:em: See TWY segments on chart AD2-LHBP-GMC
When low visibility procedures are in force the same holding positions shall be used.

e:Sub-section.x:div: Apron exit points are designated as follows:
e:Sub-section.x:p: Terminal 1:

x:tr.x:td: connection of Apron 1 and TWY D
connection of Apron 1 and TWY C
connection of Apron 1 and TWY B1
intersection TWY A1 centreline and taxilane centreline of GA Hangars area

e:Sub-section.x:p: Terminal 2:

x:tr.x:td: intersection of service road and TWY U
intersection of service road and TWY T7N
intersection of service road and TWY T7S
intersection of service road and TWY P1
intersection of service road and TWY L
intersection of service road and TWY P4

x:p.x:em: See TWY segments on Chart AD-2-LHBP PDC-1, PDC-2

e:Sub-section.e:Title: Taxi procedures for arriving aircraft
e:Sub-section.x:p: ATC expects arriving aircraft to vacate runways via the rapid exit taxiways. If unable to do accordingly, notify Budapest TWR on 118.1 MHz in advance or after landing immediately. Arrivals on RWY13R to T1 use TWY B1 or A1. Restrictions on rapid exit taxiways J4, Y and Z will be given by TWR with landing clearance. During Low Visibility Operations, pilots shall report leaving of the ILS sensitive area to Budapest TWR on 118.1 MHz.

After vacating the RWY, without further notice pilots shall immediately contact Budapest Ground on 121.900 MHz for detailed taxi instructions, if otherwise not instructed by ATC. Further taxi is allowed only as cleared by Budapest Ground or Budapest Tower to the designated exit points. Reaching the exit points, pilots shall contact the appropriate Apron Unit for further taxi guidance to the parking stands or gates, only when it is instructed by Budapest Ground or Budapest Tower. In case of no contact with the Apron Unit the aircraft shall stop and hold on the taxiway named after the designated exit point.

x:p.x:strong: The Apron Unit concerned will provide assistance for further movement.

e:Sub-section.x:p: Example:
“TAXI TO EXIT POINT LIMA”, or
“TAXI TO EXIT POINT LIMA AND CONTACT APRON 122,450”
List of available messages covering taxi clearances issued by the appropriate unit and taxi procedures for ARRIVALS in case of DUAL RUNWAY OPERATION (see taxi charts)

e:Sub-section.e:Title: Movement on aprons
e:Sub-section.x:p: With the exception of category E aircraft, aircraft may taxi to stands — 01-04, 107-109, R110-R117, 31-46, 60-64, 66-69,R220-223, R224-227, 70-79 and to aviobridges — by themselves following the painted taxi lines under good visibility conditions. Code E aircraft are escorted by “FOLLOW ME” vehicle. General aviation aircraft are always led by “FOLLOW ME” while taxiing on aprons.

Those aircraft which taxi to other than published stands or in case of LVP 2 or when taxi line markings are not visible, each aircraft will be escorted by "FOLLOW ME" vehicle to the designated stand or aviobridge.
Visual signals used by the ground staff during parking are those listed in ICAO Annex 2, Appendix 1, part 5.

Parking on the stands shall be carried out following the ground staff's visual signals; docking to aviobridges shall be made according to the signals of the SAFE-GATE VDGS system. If the VDGS system is inoperative docking shall be made following Airfield Operation Service(FOLLOW ME STAFF) instructions.

e:Sub-section.e:Title: Taxi procedures for departing aircraft
e:Sub-section.x:p: At the stand taxi guidance will be given by Budapest Apron 1 (Terminal 1) or Budapest Apron 2 (Terminal 2) to the designated exit points. Reaching the exit point, pilots shall contact Budapest Ground or Budapest Tower as instructed by the Apron Unit. Further taxiing beyond the exit point will be cleared by Budapest Ground or Budapest Tower to the designated runway holding points.
Examples, departing aircraft:

x:tr.x:td: “TAXI TO EXIT POINT UNIFORM VIA HOTEL-2”
“TAXI TO HOLDING POINT ALPHA TWO” or

e:Sub-section.e:Title: Movement on the aprons
e:Sub-section.x:p: Aircraft taxi on the aprons normally with the guidance of the Apron Unit. Aircraft shall follow the painted taxi lines. When taxiing without “FOLLOW ME” assistance pilots are responsible for safety of taxiing. When LVP2 is in force or taxi lines are not visible and the lines run close to other aircraft or obstructions, or braking action is worse than medium, aircraft are led by “FOLLOW ME” cars on the apron. When an aircraft follows the “FOLLOW ME” car, the driver of this car is responsible for obstruction free taxiing.
General aviation aircraft are always led by “FOLLOW ME” car while taxiing on aprons.

e:Sub-section.e:Title: List of available taxi clearances issued by ATC and Apron Unit
Taxi procedures for arriving aircraft (parallel RWY operation)

x:tr.x:td:
Instruction given by ATC:
“Taxi to exit point...”

x:td.x:strong: Taxi route on maneuvering area (TWY segments) to be followed

x:tr.x:td:
Guidance given by Apron Unit:
“Taxi to stand/gate...”

x:td.x:strong: Taxi route on Apron (taxilane or TWY segments) to be followed

e:Sub-section.e:Title: Taxi procedures for deparing aircraft (parallel operation)

x:tr.x:td:
Guidance given by Apron Unit:
“Taxi to exit point...”

x:td.x:strong: Taxi route on Apron(taxilane or TWY segments) to be followed

x:tr.x:td:
Instruction given by ATC:
“Taxi to holding point...”

x:td.x:strong: Taxi route on the maneuvering area (TWY segments) to be followed

e:Sub-section.e:Title: Operation of Mode S transponders when the aircraft is on the ground
e:Sub-section.x:p: A surface movement guidance and control system, using Mode-S multilateration (ASMGCS) operates at Budapest Liszt Ferenc International Airport.
Aircraft operators intending to use Budapest Liszt Ferenc International Airport shall ensure that the Mode S transponders are able to operate when the aircraft is on the ground.

e:Sub-section.e:Title: Procedures to be followed by pilots:
e:Sub-section.x:p: Select “AUTO” mode and assigned Mode A code, or if “AUTO” mode is not available, select “ON” (e.g. “XPDR”) and assigned Mode A code

x:ul.x:li: from the request for push back or taxi whichever is earlier
after landing, continuously until the aircraft is fully parked on stand, and

e:Sub-section.x:p: Select “STBY”, when fully parked on stand.

Whenever the aircraft is capable of reporting Aircraft Identification (i.e. callsign used in flight), the Aircraft Identification should also be entered from the request for push back or taxi whichever is earlier (through the FMS or the Transponder Control Panel).
Flight crew shall use the the Aircraft Identification format as defined by the ICAO (e.g. MAH602, SAS589, BAW869).
To ensure that the performance of systems based on frequencies (including airborne TCAS units and SSR radars) is not compromised

x:ul.x:li: When the aircraft is departing TCAS should not be selected before receiving the clearance to line up
When the aircraft is arriving TCAS should be deselected after vacating the runway.

e:Sub-section.x:p: For aircraft taxiing without flight plan, Mode A code 2000 should be selected

e:Sub-section.e:Title: Operation of docking system at Terminal 2A, B at stands 31-46.
e:Sub-section.x:p: At parking positions 31-46 VDGS systems (SAFE-GATE 2-18) are in operation.

e:Sub-section.e:Title: System description
e:Sub-section.x:p: The SAFEDOCK system is a microprocessor controlled laser scanning device which directs an approaching aircraft to the terminal gate stopping position with assistance of a real time display unit that is clearly visible from cockpit.

x:ol.x:li: Follow the taxi-in line to gate 31-46.
Check correct aircraft type, the flashing arrows of direction and floating arrows. (The system is activated and ready for docking procedure)

When the aircraft has been caught by the system the floating arrows replaced by the closing rate indicator.
Watch the yellow centre line indicator and the flashing arrow indicates the correct azimuth guidance.
Watch the flashing red arrows for required direction of turn.
When the aircraft is 12 m from the stop position, the closing rate is indicated by turning off one row per half meter indicating the remaining distance to the stop position
If the docking speed of the aircraft is more than 4KT, SLOW DOWN is displayed for the correct docking.
At the correct stop position all yellow closing rate indicator bars are switched off and STOP sign is displayed and 2 red lights will be lit.
When the aircraft is has parked correctly, OK sign is displayed.
When the aircraft has overshot the stop position, TOO FAR sign is displayed.

When the detection of the aircraft is not possible (the closing rate indicator does not appeared) the aircraft has to stop safety distance from the aviobridge (as primary obstacle) and has to wait for the marshaller’s manual guidance.The floating arrows indicating only that the docking system is activated and tested for the identified aircraft.

When the identification of the aircraft is not made 12 m before the correct stop position, STOP than ID FAIL sign is displayed. In this case the docking procedure has to be interrupted. The aircraft has to wait for the system restarting or for the manual guidance by the marshaller.

During heavy fog, opposite sunlight or snow the visibility of the docking system can be reduced. In this case the display deactivates the floating arrows and the SLOW sign is displayed. This configuration is superseded by the closing rate indicator bar, as soon as the system detects the approaching aircraft.

Due to distance of the aviobride the following aircraft types have to shut down the engines on the port side (left) just after turning into the centerline of the stand 31,37,42,43,44,45,46, (Boeing B737-500, B737-600, Airbus A319).

e:Sub-section.e:Title: Other procedures
e:Sub-section.x:p: The maximum taxi speed on the aprons shall not exceed 16 KT this speed shall be decreased if contamination on the surfaces deteriorates the braking action.

If departing or arriving aircraft must stop taxiing for any reason and it is necessary to open door(s), pilots shall notify appropriate unit on currently used frequency. Except cases of emergency, door(s) shall be opened only in the presence of the border guards.
In case of emergency notify appropriate unit on currently used frequency (e.g.: ATC or APRON).

e:Sub-section.e:Title: General provisions
e:Sub-section.x:div: The aim of noise abatement procedures is to mitigate the impacts of the noise generated by aircraft at the airport and on the residental areas affected by landing and takeoff procedures.
The selection of the runway to be used is performed by air traffic control (ATC) on the basis of the regulations specified below.
Aircraft operators who are demonstrably unable to comply with these regulations and procedures are obliged to report this to the National Transport Authority Directorate for Air Transport.

e:Sub-section.e:Title: In case of runway direction 31
e:Sub-section.x:p: In case of all traffic arriving to Terminal 2 and ICAO category E traffic arriving to Terminal 1, runway 31R, and, in case of traffic arriving to Terminal 1, runway 31L is to be used, but if traffic conditions require, runway 31R can also be used for landings. In case of departing traffic, runway 31L is to be used for takeoffs.

e:Sub-section.e:Title: In case of runway direction 13
e:Sub-section.x:p: In case of arriving traffic, runway 13R, and 13L with the restrictions defined in this chapter are to be used for landings. In case of traffic departing from Terminal 2 and ICAO category E traffic departing from Terminal 1, runway 13L, and, in case of ICAO category A, B, C and D category traffic departing from Terminal 1, runway 13R is to be used., but if traffic conditions require, runway 13L is to be used for takeoff.

e:Sub-section.e:Title: Nighttime (from 22:00 to 06:00 LT) – Operational regulations which differ from daytime
e:Sub-section.x:p: Primarily runway 31R and also runway 13R are to be used by arriving traffic in compliance with the prevailing legal provisions. If traffic conditions require, runway 31L may also be used for landings.
From 00:00 to 05:00 LT, runway 13L is to be used for takeoffs and runway 31R is to be used for landings.

e:Sub-section.e:Title: Restrictions on landings on runway 13L
e:Sub-section.x:p: For noise protection reasons, runway 13L may only be used for landings on working days from 08:00 to 22:00 LT by aircraft which comply at least with noise requirements of ICAO Annex 16 Vol. I., Section 3, and not exceeding a maximum takeoff weight of 100 tons, if traffic conditions require.

e:Sub-section.e:Title: Exceptions:
e:Sub-section.x:p: Deviation from the basic rules on runway use is only possible under the following circumstances:

x:ul.x:li: During the closure one of the two runways due to maintenance works, or another unexpected event;
In case of calibration flights;

If noise abatement considerations cannot be taken into account during the selection of the runway to be used, based on section 7.2 of appendix 2 of decree no. 16/2000. (XI.22.) of the Minister of Transport and Water Affairs;
If the captain of the aircraft rejects the runway use offered on the basis of noise abatement considerations, citing aviation safety reasons;
If the aircraft is in an emergency;
If no ILS approach is available on the runway selected on the basis of standard regulations.

e:Sub-section.e:Title: Arrivals
e:Sub-section.x:div: It is prohibited for arriving aircraft to perform an approach below the glide path worked out for the 3° theoretical glide path in the PAPI glide path or in the given approach procedure from FAP (Final Approach Point). Aircraft performing calibration flights are exceptions to this rule.
Noise abatement behavior expected of aircraft pilots during arrivals:

x:ul.x:li: Prior to final approach, the last reported altitude must be maintained as long as possible.

The reduction of the speed of the aircraft and the release of the landing gear and of high lift devices must be planned so that the conditions of stabilized approach and the appropriate approach speed should be in place by 5 NM from the touchdown point at the latest on final approach.
Descent during final approach should be controlled so that increases to engine power can be avoided as much as possible.
During nighttime from 22:00 to 06:00 LT the use of reverse thrust must be limited to idle thrust, except if operational circumstances require the use of a higher level of thrust.

e:Sub-section.e:Title: Departures
e:Sub-section.x:div: The use of taxiways for runway 13L/31R for departing aircraft for noise abatement reasons:

x:ul.x:li: In case of departure from runway 13L, pilots are requested by the airport operator to plan takeoff from taxiway K, if possible.

If a departing aircraft belonging in the medium or heavy turbulence category receives/is given runway 31R for takeoff, it must commence takeoff from the end of the runway, using taxiway A9, but if traffic conditions require, takeoff may also be permitted by using taxiway X.

e:Sub-section.x:div: Compliance with the standard instrument departure (SID) procedure published in the AIP is mandatory for aircraft performing IFR flights up to an elevation of QNH 7000 feet (2150 m) above mean sea level in case of runway direction 31 and up to QNH 4000 feet (1200 m) above mean sea level in case of runway direction 13, except for turboprop and light turbulence category aircraft or aircraft requesting a cruise altitude of less than 9500’.
Due to aviation safety reasons or in case of unfavorable meteorological conditions, air traffic controllers may apply a special departure procedure which differs from the SID.

Aircraft taking off according to the SID are obliged to maintain a climb gradient of at least 5.5 % up to an elevation of QNH 7000 feet (2150 m) above mean sea level in case of runway direction 31 and up to QNH 4000 feet (1200 m) above mean sea level in case of runway direction 13. If the aircraft performing the takeoff procedure is unable to maintain the minimum climb gradient of 5.5 %, it must report this to the ATC service immediately when making the first radio contact after the receipt of route clearance.

e:Sub-section.e:Title: Nighttime traffic restrictions
e:Sub-section.x:div: At nighttime, scheduled and non-scheduled commercial landings and takeoffs may only be performed subject to restrictions. The number of movements which may be planned for the nighttime is as follows:

x:ul.x:li: 50 movements between 22:00 and 06:00 LT,
Out of this, 6 movements between 00:00 and 05:00 LT.

e:Sub-section.x:div: In addition, aircraft performing patient transportation, disaster aversion, technical rescue, enforcement, criminal investigation, national security, military or government flights and those in an emergency may use the airport without restriction during nighttime.
It is prohibited to perform practice and calibration flights during nighttime from 22:00 to 06:00 LT.

e:Sub-section.e:Title: Restrictions on the use of Auxiliary Power Unit (APU)
e:Sub-section.x:div: Aircraft operators must act circumspectly regarding noise burdens arising from the use of auxiliary power units (APUs), in order to protect the area surrounding the airport, especially during nighttime from 22:00-06:00 LT.

x:ul.x:li: The operation of APUs must be stopped as soon as possible after arrival on the stand,
APUs may only be restarted for essential technical checks, or immediately prior to planned departure to ensure appropriate conditions in the passenger cabin and for electronic systems,
The operation of APUs is not permitted without the presence of trained specialist staff.

e:Sub-section.x:div: Deviation from regulations on the use of APUs during nighttime is only possible:

x:ul.x:li: Due to aviation safety reasons, or
Upon warranted requests, with permission from the duty airside manager (DAM).

e:Sub-section.x:div: During nighttime, the duty airside manager (DAM) checks airfield operational areas and warns the crews or the ground handling agent of aircraft breaching regulations on the use of APUs.

e:Sub-section.e:Title: Rules of engine testing
General
e:Sub-section.x:div: Engine testing is prohibited on the terminal aprons, except for the case described in section 3. If necessary, the air tightness checks of aircraft systems may be performed on stands 16 and 17 on terminal apron no. 1 and on stands 78 and 79 on terminal apron no. 2 at idle thrust for a maximum duration of 5 minutes, based on the permission received from the competent Apron Management unit, in compliance with the rules of engine testing.
Engine testing may only be permitted and performed at the location constructed or designated for this purpose, with the exception of the case described under section 3.

Permission for actual engine start-up must be requested from the unit of the competent department responsible for traffic management, by radio, and the completion of engine testing shall also be reported to the same unit.

e:Sub-section.e:Title: Areas designated for engine testing:

x:ol.x:li: The existing engine test area, equipped with noise mufflers, which is currently out of operation. This area is available for testing of prop or turboprop aircraft only.

B5 Holding Bay. Aircraft must be positioned in parallel with the axis of taxiway B5, so that at least ICAO category D aircraft can taxi by on the marked taxi lane without restriction, and there should be at least 50 m of load-bearing pavement behind the engine outtakes.
TWY A9
The helicopter tie-down position constructed next to the existing engine test stand.

e:Sub-section.x:div: Aircraft may only access and leave the designated areas under tow.

Between 08:00-18:00 LT, the areas designated for engine testing may be used without restriction on engine power. Between 18:00-08:00 LT, with the exception of the case specified in section 5., engines may only be operated at idle power, in accordance with section 3.

e:Sub-section.e:Title: Engine start-up for technical reasons, on idle power:

x:ol.x:li: May be performed without restriction in the areas designated for engine testing.
A maximum of one engine may be operated concurrently on terminal and technical aprons, for 5 minutes.

e:Sub-section.x:div: On the aprons, on contact stands equipped with air jetties (31-37 and 42-46), engine start-up for technical reasons is prohibited.

Engine start-ups are authorized by the competent Apron Management unit. Engine start-up at idle power may be performed regardless of the time of day. A ground technician must be present during the operation of the engine. The FTWR GRD and the Apron Management services must be informed of engine start-ups and shut-downs. Continuous radio contact must be maintained with the Apron Management and the FTWR GRD service during operation.

Engine start-up for technical reasons, at a power level higher than idle power may be performed in the areas designated for engine testing listed in section 2. between 08:00 and 18:00 LT. The duty airside manager authorizes the starting of the engine(s). The official managing engine testing is obliged to check full compliance with fire protection and labor safety regulations, and to report any fires immediately to the FTWR GRD service, which immediately alerts the airport fire service. A ground technician must be present during the operation of the engine(s). More than one engine may be operated concurrently. The FTWR GRD and the Duty Airside Management (DAM) services must be informed of engine start-ups and shut-downs. Continuous radio contact must be maintained with the FTWR GRD service during operation.

The duty airside manager may only authorize engine testing at a power level higher than idle power in areas not equipped with adequate acoustic protection between 08:00-18:00 LT. If engine testing at a power level higher than idle power is necessary between 18:00-08:00 LT, a separate prior written permit must be obtained from the National Transport Authority Directorate for Air Transport (by letter, email or fax). This permit or a copy of it shall be sent to the AOCC prior to engine testing. The engine testing performed in accordance with the authority permit is supervised and checked by the duty airside manager. In the absence of the authority permit, the duty airside manager will prohibit engine testing planned between 18:00-08:00 LT.

The operator or its agent is obliged to clean up any pollution generated during engine testing. If the operator is unable to do so, it is obliged to report this to the AOCC, who will provide for the cleaning at the operator’s cost
Budapest Airport may charge a usage fee for engine tests performed at the engine test area, the B5 holding bay and on taxiway A9.

e:Sub-section.e:Title: Limitations for arriving traffic
e:Sub-section.x:div:
If not otherwise instructed by , aircraft shall enter
Budapest at 260 KT or less,
reduce speed so as to reach 160 KT IAS before 4 NM from runway threshold.
Pilots who are unable to comply with these speed assignment, shall inform accordingly.

Due to the limited airspace available, it is of importance that the approaches to the patterns and the holding procedures are carried out as exactly as possible. Pilots are strongly requested to inform if for any reason the approach and/or holding cannot be performed as required.
Spacing on the finals are based on calculated runway occupancy times. expect all aircraft to vacate the runways within timeframes detailed as follows:

x:ul.x:li: 13R – 80 sec
13L – 60 sec
31L – 60 sec
31R – 50 sec

e:Sub-section.x:p: If aircraft are not able to vacate runway within these time frames crews are requested to notify at once.

e:Sub-section.e:Title: Handling the arriving traffic in Budapest
e:Sub-section.x:div: The conventional arrival procedures and standard instrument approach procedures for Budapest Liszt Ferenct International Airport including the radar vector technics used in the Budapest , do not do full justice to the different sorts of technology ( and/or GPS) available in many aircraft.

To guarantee optimal utilization of these modern on-board systems, so-called “Transition to final approach” procedures have been implemented at BudapestLiszt Ferenc International Airport, complying with the radar vector practice applicable for this airport.
“Transition to final approach” procedures are only offered as an option by .

To eliminates additional radio communication to clarify the navigational capability of aircraft, the phrase “unable RNAV due equipment” shall be included by the pilot immediately following the aircraft call sign, whenever initial contact on Budapest Approach frequency is established.

Transition to final approach procedures start at the transition point between area and approach control () ending at the final approach waypoint (). Each accommodate to the conventional precision approach procedure () final approach point () respective. Pilots shall ensure, that their aircraft cleared for visual approach by , to be on the runway extended centreline the latest before the final approach way point ().
e:Sub-section.x:p: In addition, optional waypoints have been defined along the procedure path (i.e. on downwind, on final) that can be used by the controllers instead of radar vectors. These waypoints are available in the navigation database of the aircraft.
Remark: - systems without navigation data bases requiring a manual data (coordinate) input are exempt from the utilization of these procedures.
e:Sub-section.x:div: By utilizing these procedures, reductions in radiotelephony communication as well as optimized flight guidance in the approach section based on realistic flight path data are possible. The turn to final approach is usually performed by radar vector or by giving the appropriate waypoint to be followed to expedite traffic handling and for separation reasons.
Transition to final approach procedures are available from each entry points to the each applicable runway.
“Transition to final approach” procedures will be used by only in radar environment.
Executive control of traffic enroute and in Budapest TMA is exercised by radar controllers. For operational use of radar See ENR 1.6
Arriving aircraft having radio communication failure shall set transponder to code 7600 and:

x:ol.x:li: During a “Transition to final approach” procedure shall continue the acknowledged procedure and also the profile of that procedure up to the FAWP, then complete the final approach for the runway in use.
Prior entering Budapest or under radar vectoring in Budapest shall proceed to TPS / and follow the standard instrument approach procedure for the runway in use.

e:Sub-section.e:Title: Instrument Approach Procedures for Budapest Liszt Ferenc International Airport
operations
e:Sub-section.x:p: Note: A change in operational status, if caused by a failure expected to last more than one hour, will be promulgated by and accordingly by ATIS. Pilots will be notified of shorter term deficiencies by ( and/or radiotelephony).

e:Sub-section.e:Title: Facilities
e:Sub-section.x:p: The data of facilities serving operations are published in AD 2-LHBP AD-2.19

e:Sub-section.e:Title: CAT III performance
e:Sub-section.x:p: The localiser for runway 31R provides full roll out guidance on total length of the runway.

e:Sub-section.e:Title: ATC Procedures for Low Visibility Conditions
Preparation Phase PREP
e:Sub-section.x:p: When the is less than 800 m and/or the cloud base is below 400 feet will apply safeguards and additional procedures to protect operations, moreover will minimize the vehicles‘ traffic on the manoeuvring areas. ATC will provide for an /LOC interception at least 8 NM from touchdown and will operate the STOPBARS and guard lights at all holding positions. In such circumstances, taxiing aircraft may continue taxiing beyond the holding position of the in use, only after the stopbar lights are switched-off, and with a specific clearance by . Furthermore without special request will operate the flashing centrelights of the approach lighting system, which will be switched-off on the request of the aircrew only.

e:Sub-section.e:Title: Operation Phase, LVP 1.
e:Sub-section.x:div: is 600 m or less and/or the cloud base is at 200 feet or below will ensure that the protection area (critical/sensitive) is clear of nontraffic before landing aircraft reaches 2 NM distance from touchdown point. In addition aircraft will be vectored to intercept the /LOC at least 10 NM from point of touchdown.

When 400 m or more responsibility to avoid collision on the manoeuvring area is shared between aircraft crew and . is responsible for insurance of safe taxi instructions, determination of priority at intersections, and provision of correct traffic information. Aircraft crew is responsible for proper execution of given taxi instructions and to avoid collision with other traffic on taxiways and at intersections by visual reference.Aircraft will be advised of these procedures in broadcast with the following expression:
e:Sub-section.x:p: “ATTENTION! LOW VISIBILITY PROCEDURES ARE IN FORCE”

e:Sub-section.e:Title: Operation Phase, LVP2.
e:Sub-section.x:p: When any of the ‘s is less than 400 m the is responsible for preventing collision between aircraft and other traffic on taxiways and intersections on the manoeuvring area.

e:Sub-section.x:div: In the above described two cases without special request will operate the flashing centre lights of the approach lighting system, which will be switched-off on the request of the aircrew only.
The above procedures are applied irrespective of the actual category of operations flown, which is a pilot's decision. During the approach pilots will be informed of:

x:ul.x:li: any known brakedown and/or downgrading of aids or facilities serving CAT. II or III operations;
significant changes in surface wind (speed and direction);
changes in .

e:Sub-section.x:p: Note: Operators shall consider that the slope of runway 31R and the building means obstacles in case of missed approach procedure, therefore 3% climbing gradient shall be used, which is more than the recommended 2,5% in the PANS-OPS.
(See AD 2-LHBP AD-2.19; Aerodrome Obstacle Chart AD 2-LHBP-AOC/A 13L/31R and AD 2-LHBP- 31R).

e:Sub-section.x:div: The movement of aircraft and vehicles on manoeuvring area will be monitored by () to avoid inadvertent runway entry and possible conflicts on taxiways.

In case of brakedown of the and/or exit taxiway stopbars, additional restrictions will be applied for safety of the aircraft moving on the manoeuvring area (e.g. start-up restriction; total vehicle movement's prohibition; etc.).

e:Sub-section.e:Title: Practice approaches
e:Sub-section.x:p: Pilots who wish to practice CAT. II or III approaches are requested to use the phrase:
“Request practice category II (or III) approach”
on initial contact with Budapest Approach. Practice approaches will be allowed only when traffic conditions permit. Pilots will be informed if the requested approach may be carried out.

e:Sub-section.e:Title: Missed approaches
e:Sub-section.x:p: The missed approach procedures do not contain level flight acceleration portion.

e:Sub-section.e:Title: Precision Approach Terrain Profile Charts
e:Sub-section.x:p: Precision Approach Terrain Profile Charts are published as AD 2-LHBP-PATC pages.

e:Sub-section.e:Title: Obstacle clearance
e:Sub-section.x:p: Obstacle clearance altitudes/heights (OCA/H) are published on the relevant Instrument Approach Charts.

e:Sub-section.e:Title: Instrument approaches
e:Sub-section.x:p: The instrument approach procedures are published on Instrument Approach Charts in Part AD 2-24.

e:Sub-section.e:Title: Visual Approach
e:Sub-section.x:p: A visual approach will only be allowed or offered if the visibility is at least 5 km and the ceiling at least 1500 ft (450m). See LHBP AD 2.22 FLIGHT PROCEDURES

e:Sub-section.e:Title: Aerodrome operating minima
e:Sub-section.x:div: The (H) values are promulgated on the instrument approach chart for each kind of approach procedures available for those categories of aircraft for which the procedure is designated. At Budapest Liszt Ferenc International Airport State weather minima are not applied.

It is assumed that an operator will establish aerodrome operating minima for his use for each kind of instrument approach procedures available. Such minima (OH) shall not be lower than the appropriate (H) value

e:Sub-section.e:Title: Initiation of an approach to land
e:Sub-section.x:p: It is assumed that an operator will formulate rules for the operations personnel concerned, regarding the initiation of an instrument approach depending on the prevailing weather conditions.

As a general rule: it is the right of the pilot-in-command to initiate an approach to land - if not otherwise regulated by the operator regardless of the weather report, as long as the aircraft does not descend below the decision altitude (height) or the minimum descent altitude /(decision height ) as may be prescribed by the operator, unless at that point the pilot-in-command finds that the actual visibility is at or above his/her applicable aerodrome operating minimum and the approach can be completed by visual reference to the ground (visual approach aids) accordingly.

e:Sub-section.e:Title: General
e:Sub-section.x:div: Flights departing from Budapest Liszt Ferenc International Airport, shall request enroute clearance before start-up from the Budapest Delivery of the Aerodrome Control Tower. See LHBP AD 2.20 LOCAL REGULATIONS
Budapest Delivery will use one of the Standard Instrument Departures published for flights, when field 15 of the flight plan contains a standard exit point.
e:Sub-section.x:p: Note: The Standard Instrument Departure procedures comprise the noise abatement procedures and clearance for climbing up to 7000 feet altitude, when the requested cruising altitude given in the flight plan equal to 7000 feet QNH or higher.
Note: Airspace restriction in force are broadcasted by
e:Sub-section.x:div: Out of cases 3.1.2 Budapest Delivery will determine individual outbound routes.
Standard Instrument Departures for flights:

x:ul.x:li: Based on para 3.1.2. and 3.1.3. the Standard Instrument Departures listed in table below will be applied by Budapest Delivery according to the runway in use.
The departure procedures in use are based on those contained in ICAO Doc 8168 OPS/611 (PANS OPS).

e:Sub-section.e:Title: Standard Instrument Departures
e:Sub-section.x:div: Differences from regulations of the Third Edition of ICAO Doc 8168-OPS/611 (PANS-OPS):
e:Sub-section.x:p: The required net climbing gradient is 5,5% up to 7000 feet , -OPS Vol. II. Part II, Chapter 2 para 2.5.1 referred.
The departure procedures do not contain level acceleration segment, -OPS Vol. II, Part II, Chapter 3 para 9.4. referred.
Pilots who are unable to comply with the assigned climbing gradient shall inform accordingly.
e:Sub-section.x:div: The required bank angle of turn is indicated on the charts (-OPS Vol. II, Part II, Chapter 3 para 3.3.1.3.1 referred).
The departure procedures are computed for aircraft maintaining 250 kt .
Strict adherence to prescribed tracks - for safety reasons and to avoid densely populated areas in the vicinity of the airport - is mandatory.

Noise abatement departure routes have been designed for aircraft departing from runways 31L and 31R. These departure routes have to be followed by “heavy” and “medium” turbulence category aircraft and “light” category jet aircraft.
Following the highest speed below FL100 is 250 kt .
Pilots are invited to execute a rolling take-off whenever possible and to avoid the significant increase of engine power, while standing in the line up position.

e:Sub-section.e:Title: Procedures for flights within Budapest and in Aerodrome Control Zone
General
e:Sub-section.x:p: ATC clearance for VFR flights within Budapest and in s will be given on the following conditions:

x:ol.x:li: Flight plan has to be submitted for request of clearance, according to 3.3.1 of ICAO Annex 2, containing the items 7 to 18 inclusive;
ATC clearance shall be obtained immediately before the aircraft enters the area concerned;
Position reports shall be submitted in accordance within 3.6.3 of ICAO Annex 2.
Deviation from the clearance may only be made, if prior permission has been obtained;
The flight shall be conducted with vertical visual reference to the ground;
Two-way radio communication shall be maintained on the frequency prescribed. Information about the appropriate frequency can be obtained from”Budapest Information”;

The aircraft shall be equipped with transponder with 4096 codes in mode A/C. Exempt from this requirement may be granted by the appropriate unit. Gliders are exempted from these requirements for flights performed within dedicated areas.

e:Sub-section.e:Title: procedures at Budapest Liszt Ferenc International Aerodrome and within Budapest (See )
e:Sub-section.x:div: Designated VFR entry and exit points to/from Budapest :
e:Sub-section.x:p: (Large warehouse 1NM NW of M5 and M0 highway junction.)
(Middle of Molnár Isle, next to Soroksár.)
(Commuter train station KEREPES – it is where the railway track divides from the highway.)
For flights operating in the north-western part of the , outside the final approach area, the following points are designated for entry/exit:
(Csepel bridge – The North end of Csepel island)
(Miklós square in Óbuda)
(Sikátorpuszta – at the crossing of motorway M3 and motor-road 2/B.)
Departing VFR flights from Budapest Liszt Ferenc International Airport shall not be planned via SIKATOR, MIKLOS, TSEPEL points.
Arriving VFR flights to Budapest Liszt Ferenc International Airport shall not be planned via TAPIO, KEREPES, SIKATOR, MIKLOS, TSEPEL points.

e:Sub-section.e:Title: Arriving aircraft
e:Sub-section.x:p: flights approaching from controlled airspace are positioned to final approach by Budapest Approach.
flights approaching from uncontrolled airspace shall enter over PAKON, and SOROK points unless otherwise instructed by Budapest TWR.
Arrival routes are determined by ATC depending on the current runway in use at Budapest Liszt Ferenc International Airport, as follows:

x:ul.x:li: In case of direction 31: PAKON - MIKE - RWY 31L landing (see visual approach chart)
In case of direction 13: SOROK - APLHA - RWY 13R landing (see visual approach chart)

e:Sub-section.x:p: Arrival routes turning points:

x:ul.x:li: MIKE: 472526N 0191539E (NDB antenna 0,6NM SE from threshold 31L)
ALPHA: 472718N 0191238E (NDB antenna 0,6NM NW from threshold 13R)

e:Sub-section.x:p: VFR holding fixes can only be used when instructed by :

x:ul.x:li: HIGHWAY (highway junction 472532N 0190905E)
LAKE (artificial lake at excavation site 472349N 0191338E)

e:Sub-section.x:p: Holding procedure has to be carried out as instructed by . Maximum holding altitude: 1500 feet .
Aeroplanes and helicopters may land on the runways. Designated Helicopter landing area is located of 13R/31L between taxiways “A” and “B”. Landing area will be designated by the on initial contact.

Entry into the final approach area designated within Budapest (see visual approach chart), allowed only for aircraft landing at Budapest Liszt Ferenc International Airport or executing special operation.
The vertical limits of the final approach are from ground up to 2000‘(600 m) AMSL and laterally bounded by straight lines connecting the following coordinates:

e:Sub-section.e:Title: Departing aircraft
e:Sub-section.x:p: Aircraft may take-off from positions listed in para. 4.2.1 above.
Departing aircraft have to follow the procedures contained in enroute clearance given before the take-off clearance.

e:Sub-section.e:Title: Taxiing
e:Sub-section.x:p: Taxiing shall be carried out as instructed by Budapest Ground or Budapest Tower and the “Follow me” car.

x:ul.x:li: Arriving aircraft: Proceed as cleared. If no landing clearance has been received, turn back and hold over the designated entry point for 5 minutes and then make landing on the designated landing area.
Departing aircraft: Do not take-off, if communication failure experienced before take-off. Return to parking position.

e:Sub-section.e:Title: Planning, authorization and execution of training flights at Budapest Liszt Ferenc International airport
Planning and authorization of training flights
e:Sub-section.x:div: Training flights shall be planned to be carried out preferably on weekdays and during working hours.
Training flights shall not be planned:

x:ul.x:li: on weekdays between 2200 - 0600 local time ();
on weekends and holidays before 0900 and after 1800 .

e:Sub-section.x:div: Training flights shall be grouped in such a way, that different exercises should follow each other, in order to avoid the continuous noise pollution of the same residential areas.
e:Sub-section.x:p: In a sequence maximum there exercises can be planned for the same route.
e:Sub-section.x:div: Notification for the execution of training flights shall be submitted one workday in advance to the Budapest Airport Zrt. Airside Operations Airport OPS Center (tel.: (+361) 296 6333, (+361) 296 6976; E-mail: vip.help@bud.hu), giving the following details:

x:ul.x:li: callsign and registration of the aircraft,
aircraft type,
the planned time of the exercise,
the nature of the exercise.

e:Sub-section.x:p: Note:- Only one training flight is allowed at any one time. No authorization is given for training when calibration flight is carried out in the below 4000’ AMSL.
The BFNR-OPS will inform the operator/crew of the aircraft about the authorization/prohibition of the training flight.
e:Sub-section.x:div: Training flights authorized before the day of exercise may be subject to restriction on the actual day only if the traffic situation, adverse weather conditions and/or technical failures ( system malfunction, radar failure, radio navigation aid failure, runway limitations, e.t.c) do not permit to give clearance for execution.

e:Sub-section.e:Title: Execution of training flights
e:Sub-section.x:p: During training flights – with the exception of emergency cases – English phraseologies shall be used.
Note:— The English expressions of the different manoeuvres which can be made after the approaches are listed in para 5.2.1 d) below.
e:Sub-section.x:div: Flight procedures for aircraft of heavy and medium wake turbulence category, and for light jet aircraft

x:ol.x:li:
Practising engine failure
Follow the prescribed track during low approach until passing noise-sensitive areas. In the case of short visual circuit the exercise can be started only after passing the built-up areas and at a level from which the approach can be completed without operating the running engine on full power over residential areas.

e:Sub-section.e:Title: procedures
e:Sub-section.x:div: If the requires the aircraft to discontinue the approach and to turn in a defined direction and/or to climb, the expression”CANCEL, I SAY AGAIN CANCEL APPROACH” is used and supplemented with further instructions, as necessary (e.g. TURN RIGHT HEADING 040 and CLIMB TO 2500’ …).

If the requires the aircraft to carry out the missed approach procedure published in the AIP, the expression”GO AROUND, I SAY AGAIN GO AROUND EXECUTE MISSED APPROACH PROCEDURE!” is used and supplemented with further climb/heading instructions, as necessary.

e:Sub-section.e:Title: Ground Handling Organizations
e:Sub-section.x:p: Organization(s) dealing with the ground handling of passengers, freight and mail, as well as providing apron service. Their work shall be carried out on the area designated to them according to the permission of the airport operator. Their services shall be ordered by aircraft operators. The permit for carrying out special activity issued by the operator of the airport does not substitute the required permits issued by the responsible authorities.

Regarding capacity, for the best use of the equipment available at the airport, the conditions and way of the use of runways, aprons as well as airport buildings shall be determined by the operator of the airport, the Budapest Airport Zrt. according to the relevant rules of law and considering the regulations of economic efficiency and environment protection.
The above as well as para (2) point c) of Government Decree No. 141/1995. (XI.30.) 21. § regulate the order of ground handling according to the following.
Ground handling organizations operate at Budapest Liszt Ferenc International Airport:

x:ul.x:li: Malév GH [pax/cargo]malevdhm@malev.hu (+3620) 4546-057
Celebi GH [pax/cargo]dhm@celebi.hu (+3630) 2029-048
Farnair GH [cargo]vle@farnair.hu (+3630) 2780-761
Menzies Aviation [pax]tibor.fazekas@menziesaviation.com (+3620) 2203-266

e:Sub-section.e:Title: Supervision of the Aerodrome
e:Sub-section.x:p: The movement areas at Budapest Liszt Ferenc International Airport are checked on a regular basis by the Duty Airside Manager. The Duty Airside Manager will advise the units concerned about the prevailing conditions of the runways and other parts of the movement area.
Runway state information and other related information of direct operational significance will be distributed to operators and services concerned either by or as appropriate.
Information on aerodrome conditions (including weather conditions) and limitations of available services and/or facilities will be announced also in broadcast.

e:Sub-section.e:Title: Automatic Terminal Information Service (ATIS) Broadcasts

x:ol.x:li: Name of aerodrome
Designator
Time of observation
Type of approach to be expected and runway(s) in use
Significant runway surface conditions and if appropriate braking action; conditions of other movement areas
Expected delay, if appropriate
Transition level
Other essential operational information
Meteorological report
information

e:Sub-section.x:p: Pilots of arriving and departing aircraft are requested to report receipt of ATIS broadcast by reading back relevant designator of information and on initial contact with Budapest Approach or Budapest Ground respectively.
Notes:

x:ul.x:li: One broadcast is serving both arriving and departing aircraft.

Runway braking action is reported with friction coefficient, or estimated braking action if friction coefficient is not available. It is transmitted for each third of the runway in use commencing from the threshold. Sections of the runway are identified as first part, second part, and third part.
values are transmitted in the following order: touchdown zone, mid point and stop end. When s for all the three positions are available, the positions are not identified.

e:Sub-section.e:Title: Bird flocks and bird migrations
e:Sub-section.x:p: The size of flocks of birds living at or near Budapest Liszt Ferenc International Airport varies with seasons.

Domestic pigeons bred at settlements in the vicinity of the airport represent a constant and growing threat. Appearance of a flock comprising 50 to 100 individuals can be expected from every direction between 30 and 100 feet.
About 40 to 60 birds of prey live within the area or in the immediate vicinity of the airport. Birds of prey are a hazard to aircraft in the initial climb or final approach phase of flight.
Danger of collision somewhat increases in June- August when the new generation leave their nests.

Bird migrations occur, depending on weather conditions, in February-March and in September-October. In these months flocks of several thousand, relatively small, birds will migrate through the airspace at varying altitudes.
Between November and February gulls also appear at the airport, usually preferring to settle on runways and taxiways.

Particular mention must be made of black and grey crows. Between October and March - also depending on weather conditions - they migrate through the airspace of the airport in flocks of several ten thousand, sometimes of several hundred thousand, and settle temporarily on the airfield.
Their migration shows a distinct daily pattern: after dawn they fly from to , at dusk from to , between 30 and 1000 feet.

e:Sub-section.e:Title: Bird Watch and Scaring Service
e:Sub-section.x:p: The Budapest Airport Zrt. operates a continuous bird watch and scaring service, with adequate equipment.
Operators using Budapest Liszt Ferenc International Airport are requested to send their comments relating to the operation of this service to the following address:
Airside Management
BUD International Airport Zrt.

e:Sub-section.e:Title: Reporting a Bird Strike
e:Sub-section.x:p: Operators using Budapest Liszt Ferenc International Airport are requested to report events of bird strike by filling in the ICAO standard “BIRD STRIKE REPORTING FORM” (BSRF). The form can be obtained - and filed - at the Air Traffic Services Reporting Office.

If the event occurs after take-off and the crew do not consider it necessary to interrupt their flight, then they should notify the via radio, then fill in the BSRF at their destination airport and send it to the following address:
Airside Management
BUD International Airport Zrt.

(RWY 13R) - GPS/FMS RNAV ARRIVAL CHART - TRANSITION TO FINAL APPROACH
